description.narrative: The objective of this project is to contribute to the incorporation of the voices, demands and concerns for inclusive peace and reconciliation of minority groups in the political transition in Afghanistan. In order to achieve this, minorities have to be incorporated in the ongoing peace debates and negotiations. The expected results of the project are: 1. The establishment of a consultative process for various Afghan ethnic groups to openly and safely discuss their perceptions on active involvement of smaller minority groups in the ongoing peace process, and to participate in the implementation of a research that explores how to build an inclusive peace in the country. 2. Suggestions for a new inclusion mechanism and policy that will be discussed among the Afghan civil society, government and academic institutions as a result of the Policy Briefing Report published at the end of the project. 3. An increase in the awareness of the Afghan citizens on the ongoing peace process and peace inclusiveness, that ensures engagement of smaller minority groups in sustainable peace building. 4. An advancement of minorities’ civil and political rights through group discussion, interview, policy report and other interactive exposures with different groups, which will create a democratic space for inclusion of isolated minorities. 5. Providing smaller minority groups with an opportunity to enhance agency to meaningful participation, raise up their voice, demands and engage in conversation on peace process at various levels of Afghan society.

Det övergripande målet med detta projekt är att bidra till att minoriteters röster, förväntningar och farhågor förs in i afghanska fredsprocesser, och att verka för en inkluderande fred och försoning i Afghanistan.
The overall goal of this project is the incorporation of non-dominant minorities’ voices, demands and concerns for an inclusive peace and reconciliation in Afghanistan.

description.narrative: In the first months of implementation, CSHRN and HREVO have finalised a Inclusive Peace Guidebook, a Leaflet on Inclusive Peace, and developed a research outline. For the development of the research outline, the organisations initiated a mapping to establish statistics of where minority populations live on three levels: the provincial level, district level and the village level, since they quickly realised that existent government data was to a large degree lacking. Data collection to complement this mapping also included information on primary occupations, critical challenges in life, general security situation and information about their minority community. This mapping is part of ensuring that the planned population targets research survey on minority needs and demands is representative of the population. A manual on inclusivity in the peace process in the Afghan context was developed to serve as the base for project activities in this project. The manual intended to introduce actors in the Afghan peace processm in particular representatives of minority groups, to peace, the impact of inclusivity in peace processes and its relation to more durable outcomes, different stages of peace processes, and available tools and models practices on inclusion for minority groups to influence the peace process. The manual was translated into dari and Pashtu and 500 copies have been printed and will continue to be shared among peace actors within civil society. The aim is that the manual will be able to help civil society actors and other groups to design and better implement projects aimed at enhancing the position of civil society acors in the peace process. The peacebuilding leaflet that was developed contains issues on peacebuilding, inclusive peace and peace modalities from the manual. Thus far, 1000 copies have been printed, and will be distributed among Focus Group Discussions (FGDs) to help develop samle models for inclusion in the peace process. Public awareness-raising has been conducted, as well as mobilisation of minority groups in close coordination with minority organisations and councils which led to the establishment of an Advocacy Committee for Minorities' inclusion in the Peace Process, which will provide a platform for advocacy and monitoring of the peace process in order to ensure that the demands, needs and concerns of minority groups are met.
